OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Made cancer cells on omentum more visible; made the omentum tissue look more shear and less like gray stripes.
Added the omentum; removed the cancer cells inset and moved the cancer cells to the omentum, based on reviewer's comments.

Removed the cancer spot that is on the right fallopian tube near the top of the uterus; moved the letter “b” in the Cancer cells inset down and to the right so that it isn’t right on top of the cells.

Removed the cancer spots that aren’t in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, and in the lymph nodes; removed the cancer that is growing out of the ovaries onto adjacent tissue; added a small letter “a” next to the cancer in the lymph nodes; added a small letter “b” inside the little inset box with the microscopic cancer, and changed the label in that box from “Cancer” to “Cancer cells”.

REVISED IMAGE per FIGO update: Removed "ovarian cancer" from title; added the lymph node group that is shown on the lower, left side of the Stage IIIC illustration, and put cancer in some of the nodes and labeled it “Lymph nodes with cancer”.
Added a box around the peritoneum and connected it to the pullout.

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Drawing of stage IIIA shows cancer inside both ovaries that has spread to (a) lymph nodes behind the peritoneum. Also shown is (b) microscopic cancer cells that have spread to the omentum. The small intestine, colon, fallopian tubes, uterus, and bladder are also shown.

Drawing of stage IIIA shows cancer inside both ovaries that has spread to (a) lymph nodes behind the peritoneum. Also shown is (b) microscopic cancer cells that have spread to the omentum. The small intestine, colon, fallopian tubes, uterus, and bladder are also shown.

Captions.MediaCaption: In stage IIIA, cancer is found in one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes and (a) cancer has spread to lymph nodes in the area outside or behind the peritoneum only, or (b) cancer cells that can be seen only with a microscope have spread to the omentum. Cancer may have spread to nearby lymph nodes.

In stage IIIA, cancer is found in one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes and (a) cancer has spread to lymph nodes in the area outside or behind the peritoneum only, or (b) cancer cells that can be seen only with a microscope have spread to the omentum. Cancer may have spread to nearby lymph nodes.

MediaContent.Comment: 2016-01-26: Revised content & caption approved by OCC; added HP content & caption.
